headline: U.S. jobless claims tumble in latest week, painting a picture of a strong labor market
author: Greg Robb
sentences: Looking ahead: The overall picture painted by these data points to a rapid pace of job growth, although with the supply of labor still constrained,‚Äù said Josh Shapiro, chief economist at MFR Inc.

Economic Report
Continuing claims at lowest level since 1970
The numbers: Initial jobless benefit claims fell by 17,000 to 232,000 in the week ended Feb. 19, the Labor Department said Thursday.
Key details: The number of people already collecting jobless benefits fell by 112,000 to 1.48 million in the week ended Feb. 12.
Big picture: Claims had risen to a three-week high in the prior week, but the gain was seen as statistical noise.
Overall, the labor market is seen as very tight and economists think claims will continue to move lower.
Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal had estimated new claims would slip to 235,000.
These so-called continuing claims are at their lowest level since March 1970.
